review.title: Recommending the Most Encompassing Opposing and Endorsing Arguments in Debates
review.abstract: Arguments are essential objects in DirectDemocracyP2P, where they can occur both in association with signatures for petitions, or in association with other debated decisions, such as bug sorting by importance. The arguments of a signer on a given issue are grouped into one single justification, are classified by the type of signature (e.g., supporting or opposing), and can be subject to various types of threading.

sections.heading: 5 Conclusion
sections.text: We propose a logical framework for thinking about arguments in debates. It is a kind of abstract reasoning framework and can be used to recommend relevant opinions to readers navigating the debate graphics. This framework is particularly relevant for debates where arguments (which are considered as nuclear entities in an attack / support relationship) are presented in a decentralized manner by a number of participating colleagues. This framework is designed as a mechanism for making recommendations in the DirectDemocracyP2P.net system.

metadata.abstractText: Arguments are essential objects in DirectDemocracyP2P, where they can occur both in association with signatures for petitions, or in association with other debated decisions, such as bug sorting by importance. The arguments of a signer on a given issue are grouped into one single justification, are classified by the type of signature (e.g., supporting or opposing), and can be subject to various types of threading. Given the available inputs, the two addressed problems are: (i) how to recommend the best justification, of a given type, to a new voter, (ii) how to recommend a compact list of justifications subsuming the majority of known arguments for (or against) an issue. We investigate solutions based on weighted bipartite graphs.
